section-block.rac_body-text: As a group, stack small-, medium-, and large-sized blocks. Point out that the larger blocks hold up taller stacks the best. Ask children what they like to build.
Invite children to sing verses of “This Is the Way,” and act out building scenarios. Have them name their actions, such as “I’m chopping wood” or “I’m nailing down boards.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Little Red Fort by Brenda Maier.
Scout is interested in building. I wonder what we will learn about building from the main character in this narrative, or story.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready? How do people work together to build something?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Ruby find? What does she want to do?
Why don’t Ruby’s brothers want to help her build? What are they doing instead?
What do Ruby’s brothers do when she asks them to help her draw the plans?
How will drawing plans help Ruby build a fort? What is something that you have planned?
Look at the illustration on this page. Does anyone help Ruby build her fort? Who do you think might be helping her?
Why do you think Ruby’s brothers finally make things for Ruby’s fort?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do people work together to build something?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then use Equity Sticks to call on individual children who want to respond.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They help each other be more careful.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about building and creating.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do people plan or play before they build something?
People pl_____ (plan) before they build something.
People plan before they build something.
How did Ruby’s brothers help her build her fort?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children use building blocks, they are exploring the scientific principles of height, balance, and gravity. Asking them questions about what they’re doing and what they observe reinforces these principles.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Persist in Solving Problems
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about a time when children persisted with a goal, such as when building a fort or completing a puzzle. What problems did they face, and how did they solve them? Explain that it’s important to keep trying, stick to a goal, and ask for help when needed.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the persistence Mind Builder as we reread the book, The Little Red Fort by Brenda Maier.
This fiction story is about a girl named Ruby who builds a fort. Clifford is interested in stories about characters who build things.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread a few pages that give us some clues about Ruby.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does it mean that Ruby’s mind is “always filled with ideas”? What do you see in the illustrations that show you some of Ruby’s ideas? (MB)
What does Ruby say when her brothers tell her that she doesn’t know how to build anything? How can you learn how to do something new? (MB)
What does Ruby do before she starts building? Why does she do this? (MB)
When Ruby’s creation is complete, what does she ask? What do her brothers say?
What do Ruby’s brothers make? How does Ruby feel? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Reinforce the concept of persisting in solving problems by having children work with partners to plan something they want to build. Use age-appropriate materials such as log cabin toy sets, interlocking bricks, or sticky foam beads. As children build, encourage them to share their ideas, use persistence, and try to complete their building. Ask children whether working together to build something made it easier and more fun.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about building and creating.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: In the preK classroom, persisting in attempting to solve problems can happen anytime and anywhere. Explicit and direct role-playing serves as skill-building before problems occur. One of the best ways to teach emotional and executive function skills is by role-playing, which provides an authentic scenario in a safe space. (Thomas and Thorne, 2009)

section-block.rac_body-text: Make connections by reading the back page of The Little Red Fort. Which story is it like? Review the Share the MC Strategy Card.
Practice making connections between texts by also reading or retelling The Little Red Hen. Compare each main character’s ideas and how they begin to build.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book The Little Red Fort by Brenda Maier.
Scout is making connections about this story because he works a lot with others, and sometimes he has to solve problems. (MB)
You can think about this guiding question as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can working with others help you solve problems?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during rereading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happens when Ruby finds some old boards? What do her brothers say to her?
What does Ruby gather before she starts to build?
What does Ruby ask after she has gathered supplies? What does she do next?
Look at the illustration. How does Ruby’s grandmother help? How does Ruby help her grandmother?
What does Ruby tell her brothers when they want to play in her fort? What do Ruby’s brothers do next?
Did you make connections as we read today? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can working with others help you solve problems?
section.rac_body-text: Give one minute for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share out.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: It helps to think of more ideas.
It helps us learn to work together.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about building and creating.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does working together make carrying things easier or harder?
Working together makes carrying things e________ . (easier)
Working together makes carrying things easier.
What is something we can build better together than by ourselves?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Conversational Language and Sentence Structure
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children learn authentically when it comes to conversational language. That’s why it’s so important to set up your classroom for conversation. As children create independently, engage their conversational know-how by asking how something works and what their goals are for their creations.

section-block.rac_body-text: Compare houses built with materials such as brick, wood, mud, and ice. Show children pictures of these houses and ask what they think they are made of.
Set out drinking straws and interlocking bricks. Challenge children to build with both materials, then discuss why a straw is not a good building material.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week, we are going to read The Three Little Rabbits. It is a story on a poster. The pictures on the front tell about the longer story on the back, which I will read. Each picture has a caption that tells what is happening.
Scout likes to point as he reads captions. The captions are words that tell about the illustrations.
The Little Red Fort and The Three Little Rabbits are two texts about building a shelter. What shelters do we see in the stories? Let’s find other connections between these two texts.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show The Little Red Fort cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to the weekly concept and this week’s concept question:
Why do we build things?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to share.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Mama Rabbit say to Ryan, Ricardo, and Rebecca when they want to build their own houses?
What does Ryan Rabbit use to build his house? Is his house strong? How do you know?
What does Ricardo use to build his house? What does the Big Bad Wolf do to Ricardo’s house?
What happens when the Big Bad Wolf tries to blow Rebecca’s house down? Is Rebecca’s house strong? How do you know?
What do Ryan and Ricardo learn? Will what they learned make Mama Rabbit happy? Why?

section.rac_body-text: Have groups recreate the story with toys or as a role-play activity.
Provide a writing prompt about building. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As children read and listen, they naturally make connections between new stories and those they have previously read. Help children make connections with open-ended requests like, “Tell me more about that,” or “Give me more details.” Then restate: “You’re thinking about a few different stories with a Big Bad Wolf character.”

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children work together to act out building an imaginary house using imaginary tools. Have them decide who will do which imaginary job (cut the boards, hammer the nails, put on the roof, paint). Ask how big the house will be. Have children stretch out their arms and reach high to show how big the house will be. Ask what they will do when they are finished.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread The Little Red Fort by Brenda Maier. As we listen, I want you to watch for one important part in the story: the part where Ruby’s brothers huddle together to think.
This is a narrative, or story, but it seems like it could happen in real life. Scout loves to read realistic fiction because it gives him ideas.

This week, we meet a girl named Ruby in our story. She decides to build a fort and asks her brothers to help her. As we read the story one more time, I want you to think about the guiding question: How can working together make it easier to build something?

section.rac_body-text: Retell and reenact the book together, focusing on the ways the characters build and create. Use Equity Sticks to pick groups of children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Ruby’s mind is always full of ideas. Is your mind full of ideas? Draw a plan of something you want to build. Have a partner guess what it is.
Pretend you are Ruby. What would you say or do to convince someone to help you build something?
Work with a small group to act out the word huddle. What did you do to act it out?
What delicious surprise does Ruby share with her brothers after they help? Act out eating something delicious and have a partner guess what it is.
Look at the illustrations on these pages. How do you think Ruby and her brothers are feeling? What does this show you about working together to build something?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to discuss the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can working together make it easier to build something?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about building, then share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does working together get the job done faster or slower?
Working together gets the job done f ________ . (faster)
Working together gets the job done faster.
How can people share ideas—even if their ideas are different?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Build a community of learners by allowing children to work among themselves when it comes to activities like building a tower. When children are engaging with each other on a team, they are not only learning from other children but can in turn teach other children.
